meta.title: Develop a digital technologies outcome
meta.purpose: Students are able to develop a digital technologies outcome.

grade_descriptors.N1: Evidence does not reach the minimum threshold for Achieved-level indicators.
grade_descriptors.N2: Some Achieved-level indicators are met, but not enough to satisfy all required Achieved criteria.
grade_descriptors.A3: All Achieved-level indicators are met; no Merit-level indicator meets the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.A4: All Achieved indicators are met and at least one Merit indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.M5: All Achieved indicators are met and the Merit threshold is reached; no Excellence-level indicator meets the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.M6: All Achieved indicators are met, all Merit indicators are met, and at least one Excellence indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.E7: All Achieved and Merit indicators are met and the Excellence threshold is reached, but not all Excellence indicators are met.
grade_descriptors.E8: All Achieved, Merit, and Excellence indicators are met.

key_terms.definition: An outcome that addresses the requirements and specifications, considers potential users and context, and performs as intended.
The student examining their own outcome, or parts of it.
Having other people use the outcome, or parts of it, to determine suitability for users; this process should include end user(s).
Established practices within the chosen digital technologies domain.
Applying tools or techniques in the best way practicable for a particular task.

omis.description: Describes the purpose of the outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Look for a clear statement, in the learner’s own words, explaining what the outcome is for and why it matters in its context. A brief title or text copied from the task is insufficient; it should indicate intended function and value.
success_examples: The purpose of the outcome is to create an online dashboard to monitor soil moisture for houseplants.
This site helps Year 9 students quickly find after-school club details and sign up on their phones.
omis.typical_evidence: Intro paragraph in the brief; narrated demo stating purpose; teacher attestation that the learner articulated purpose.

omis.description: Identifies the potential users of the outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Identify who will realistically use or benefit from the outcome. Generic audiences (e.g., “everyone”) are insufficient. A single authentic user is acceptable if well described; multiple users preferred.
success_examples: The users are game developers.
The users are plant owners who want to monitor soil moisture remotely.
Target users are student leaders who collect lunchtime sign-ups on shared tablets.
omis.typical_evidence: Named roles/personas; device targets; rationale linking user to purpose.

omis.description: Describes the requirements and measurable specifications of the outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Expect several broad requirements (what it must do/contain) AND measurable specifications (how success will be verified). These should be personalised to this outcome, not copied from the task. Specifications should include quantifiable or checkable criteria.
success_examples: Requirement: soil moisture reading must update every 10 seconds; Specification: reading resolution ±1%; webpage must fetch new data within 0.5 s.
Requirement: the website should include at least two linked pages and an image gallery; Specification: passes HTML/CSS validation with zero errors and displays correctly in Chrome and Safari.
Requirement: printable poster must include the school logo and key event info; Specification: print test shows correct colour and text readability at A4 size.
omis.typical_evidence: Bulleted list in planning doc; testable acceptance criteria table; rubric-aligned spec sheet.

omis.description: Uses appropriate tools or techniques of a digital technologies domain to produce the outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Evidence should show purposeful application of domain tools or techniques beyond following a tutorial. Name the tool AND describe what was done with it (actions, features used, settings). For games: custom assets/layouts or mechanics; for web: semantic HTML/CSS/JS.
success_examples: On the Arduino, I used analogRead() on the moisture sensor and converted it to a percentage. I set up an HTTP server returning JSON. On the webpage, I used JavaScript fetch() every 10 seconds to pull data and update the display.
In Godot I created a tilemap for level layout, added a KinematicBody2D with movement and jump physics, and scripted collision checks for hazards.
In Canva I used grid layout and alignment tools to create consistent spacing, ensuring readable typography and balanced composition.
omis.typical_evidence: Code snippets; annotated screenshots of tool settings; asset pipeline notes; commit messages.

omis.description: Shows that the produced outcome addresses the stated requirements and specifications.
omis.detection_hint: Look for explicit mapping from outcome features to requirements/specs using linking language (e.g., “so that…”, “therefore it meets…”). It is acceptable to note any unmet specifications; commentary should acknowledge gaps.
success_examples: The webpage navigation uses internal links and displays the gallery correctly (requirement met).
Text and images align within margins on both print and screen versions, addressing design requirements.
Testing shows all links work and images scale correctly across browsers as specified.
omis.typical_evidence: Traceability table (Req/Spec → Evidence); screenshots with validation; brief note of any unmet specs.

omis.description: Tests the outcome to ensure basic functionality.
omis.detection_hint: Must show the outcome operating in a context close to intended use (e.g., browser/device types, sensor interaction, 3D print/render). Statements of intent are insufficient. Teacher attestation is acceptable if it describes what was observed working.
success_examples: I loaded the webpage in two browsers and confirmed that navigation links and images displayed correctly.
I printed the poster and checked for correct layout and readable text.
I ran the Arduino program and verified that the LED indicator changed when the sensor was covered.
omis.typical_evidence: Short video demo; screenshots of multi-browser checks; 3D print photo; teacher attestation of observed function.
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p1 Explanatory Note 1 • Achieved

omis.description: Follows conventions relevant to the tools or techniques of the chosen digital technologies domain.
omis.detection_hint: Locate concrete evidence of conventions: e.g., semantic HTML, indentation and comments, external CSS, lower-case no-space filenames, organised /images /css /js folders, wiring colour norms, sensible variable naming. Claims without evidence are insufficient.
success_examples: Used index.html, styles.css, script.js in organized folders; Arduino sketch named PlantMonitor.ino; consistent indentation in HTML, CSS, JS.
HTML validated; heading hierarchy applied; CSS uses multiple selectors and shorthand where appropriate.
Database queries follow SQL naming conventions and use consistent casing for fields.
omis.typical_evidence: Repository tree; validator screenshots; code excerpts; photos of wiring; naming/structure checklist.
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p1 Explanatory Note 1 • Merit

omis.description: Uses information from testing to make improvements to the outcome’s fitness for purpose.
omis.detection_hint: Expect at least two specific improvements directly linked to the learner’s own functional testing (cause → change → improved result). Proof-reading or fixing validator warnings alone is not sufficient unless the fitness-for-purpose gain is explained.
success_examples: Image alignment was inconsistent; I adjusted the CSS grid and confirmed layout consistency on re-test.
In testing, a button overlapped text on smaller screens; I modified the layout to maintain readability.
Print preview cut off the footer; I resized margins and confirmed full visibility on A4 print.
omis.typical_evidence: Before/after screenshots; test table (Issue → Change → Result); commit notes referencing tests.
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p1 Explanatory Note 1 • Merit

omis.description: Demonstrates conventions in process artifacts or code/layout (e.g. structure, tags, grouping).
omis.detection_hint: Find conventions visible within the artefacts themselves (folder layout, code formatting, naming patterns, grouped functions). Documentation claims are not enough without artefact proof.
success_examples: HTML conventions have been followed, with indented code and correct tags.
Project folder has /css, /js, /assets; JS functions grouped logically; Arduino code uses consistent variable naming and comments.
Database queries use consistent casing and aliases; tables structured with appropriate datatypes.
omis.typical_evidence: Repo/file tree capture; code excerpts; SQL screenshots; linter/formatter outputs.

omis.description: Applies tools or techniques optimally to produce a fit-for-purpose outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Show skilled, efficient, and context-aware application (e.g., semantic HTML + external CSS + shorthand; efficient datatypes and queries; constants and formulae in sketches; power/network efficiency in embedded). If nothing is clearly non-optimal for Level 1, an optimal judgement may be appropriate.
success_examples: I used WebSockets instead of polling to reduce network load; on the Arduino I used sleep modes between readings to save power.
CSS extracted to external file; multiple selectors and cascade used to reduce duplication; images sized appropriately before upload.
In database design, tables were normalised and datatypes selected to minimise redundancy and ensure accurate queries.
omis.typical_evidence: Code diffs; performance logs; schematic choices with rationale; validator passes tied to design choices.
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p1 Explanatory Note 1 • Excellence

omis.description: Trials the outcome with others, including end users.
omis.detection_hint: Evidence must show other people actually used the outcome (hands-on). End-user involvement is recommended but not mandatory. Opinions alone without use are insufficient.
success_examples: I asked classmates and a plant hobbyist to load the webpage on their devices and monitor plant moisture over a day.
Two students used the website to join clubs during interval; they reported the icons were unclear on smaller screens.
Family members printed and read the brochure, giving feedback about colour contrast and clarity.
omis.typical_evidence: Short trial log (who, device, what they did, issues); photos/screens of users interacting; quick survey linked to use session.

omis.description: Uses information from trialling with others to improve the outcome’s fitness for purpose.
omis.detection_hint: Improvements must clearly trace to user or end-user feedback and strengthen alignment to purpose, users, requirements, or specifications. Document the feedback → change → improved result link.
success_examples: User feedback said the gauge color was confusing, so I changed from red/green to a gradient and re-trialled; users said it was clearer.
End users couldn’t find ‘Join’ on mobile; I moved it to the first screen and increased contrast; re-trial showed zero misses.
Trial users noted small font on printed brochure; I increased font size and spacing, improving readability.
omis.typical_evidence: Trial notes with quotes; before/after screenshots; brief re-trial confirmation; checklist showing improved spec compliance.
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p1 Explanatory Note 1 • Excellence

change_log: Removed web page-load references; aligned success examples with official Moderator Guide exemplars (v3, Oct 2025).
